company.name: Monarch Services, Inc.
company.business_description: Monarch Services, Inc. operates www.girlslife.com, a website directed to children and young teenagers. The company displays online advertising, sells products such as print magazine subscriptions, apparel, books, candy, jewelry, music, and novelties, and promotes third-party products and websites through its platform.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

complaint.factual_background: Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc. operated a website directed to children (www.girlslife.com) that collected extensive personal information from children under 13 through contests, bulletin boards, email accounts, and other activities. The defendants failed to comply with COPPA requirements, including failing to post adequate privacy policies, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting children's personal information, failing to provide parents with notice or means to review collected information, and conditioning children's participation on disclosing more information than reasonably necessary.

counts.title: Insufficient Privacy Policy Notice on Website
counts.representation: Defendants were required to provide sufficient notice on their website of what information they collect online from children, how they use such information, their disclosure practices, and all other required content
counts.fact: Prior to approximately October 18, 2000, defendants did not post any privacy policy. Since then, defendants have posted a privacy policy, but it does not clearly, understandably, or completely disclose all of their information collection, use, and disclosure practices and other disclosures required by the Rule. Defendants' privacy policy is posted only on their website's homepage, and not in close proximity to every place where defendants request personal information
counts.conclusion: Failing to provide sufficient notice on the website of what information they collect online from children, how they use such information, their disclosure practices, and all other required content, in violation of Section 312.4(b) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b)

counts.title: Failure to Provide Direct Notice to Parents
counts.representation: Defendants were required to provide notice to parents of their practices regarding the collection, use, and/or disclosure of children's personal information and other disclosures required by the Rule
counts.fact: Defendant does not provide direct notice to parents of its practices regarding the collection, use, and/or disclosure of children's personal information and other disclosures required by the Rule
counts.conclusion: Failing to provide notice to parents of what information they collect online from children, how they use such information, their disclosure practices, and all other required content, in violation of Section 312.4(c) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c)

counts.title: Failure to Obtain Verifiable Parental Consent
counts.representation: Defendants were required to obtain verifiable parental consent for collecting, using, or disclosing the personal information of children
counts.fact: Defendants fail to obtain verifiable parental consent for collecting, using, or disclosing the personal information of children
counts.conclusion: Failing to obtain verifiable parental consent before any collection, use, and/or disclosure of personal information from children, in violation of Section 312.5 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.5

counts.title: Failure to Provide Notice Under Exception to Prior Consent
counts.representation: In situations falling under an exception to the Rule's prior parental consent requirement, defendants were required to provide parents with notice and the opportunity to request that the operator make no further use of the information
counts.fact: In situations falling under an exception to the Rule's prior parental consent requirement, defendants failed to provide parents with notice and the opportunity to request that the operator make no further use of the information
counts.conclusion: In situations falling under an exception to the Rule's prior parental consent requirement, failing to provide parents with notice and the opportunity to request that the operator make no further use of the information, in violation of Sections 312.4(c) and 312.5(c) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. §§ 312.4(c) and 312.5(c)

counts.title: Failure to Provide Parental Access and Review
counts.representation: Defendants were required to provide a reasonable means for parents to review the personal information collected from their children and to refuse to permit its further use or maintenance
counts.fact: Defendants provide no means for parents to review or delete the information collected from their children
counts.conclusion: Failing to provide a reasonable means for parents to review the personal information collected from their children and to refuse to permit its further use or maintenance, in violation of Section 312.6 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.6

counts.title: Conditioning Participation on Excessive Information Collection
counts.representation: Defendants were prohibited from conditioning children's participation in an activity on their disclosing more personal information than is reasonably necessary to participate in such activity
counts.fact: The personal information collected is more than what is reasonably necessary for children to participate in these activities
counts.conclusion: Conditioning children's participation in an activity on their disclosing more personal information than is reasonably necessary to participate in such activity, in violation of Section 312.7 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.7

definitions.Rule: the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312, or as the Rule may hereafter be amended.
definitions.child, collects, collection, Commission,: defined as those terms are defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.defendants: Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc. and their officers; and each of the above's successors and assigns, agents, representatives, and employees.

provisions.title: Injunction Against Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule.

requirements.description: Must not violate any provision of the COPPA Rule
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, their successors and assigns, and their officers, agents, servants, employees and attorneys, and all persons in active concert or participation with any one or more of them who receive actual notice of this Consent Decree by personal service or otherwise, are hereby enjoined from violating, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, website, or other device, any provision of the Rule as promulgated and as it may be modified in the future.

provisions.title: Consumer Education Notice
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must place a clear and conspicuous notice on children-directed websites linking to the FTC's children's privacy information page.

requirements.description: Post FTC notice in privacy policy, parent notices, and data collection locations
requirements.quoted_text: For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall, in connection with the operation of any website or online service directed in whole or in part to children, place a clear and conspicuous notice (1) within the privacy policy required to be posted on its website(s) by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b); (2) within the direct notice required to be sent to parents by Section 312.4(c) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c); and (3) at each location on its website(s) where personal information is collected, which states as follows in bold typeface: NOTICE: Visit www.ftc.gov/kidzprivacy for information from the Federal Trade Commission about protecting children's privacy online.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay a civil penalty of $30,000 to the United States, jointly and severally.

requirements.quoted_text: Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc., and their successors and assigns, shall pay to plaintiff a civil penalty, pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A), in the amount of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000). Defendants are jointly and severally responsible for paying the penalty.

provisions.title: Payment Method and Timing
provisions.summary: Defendants must make the civil penalty payment on the date of entry by certified or cashier's check.

requirements.description: Make payment by certified or cashier's check on date of entry
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc., and their successors and assigns, shall make the payment required by Paragraph 8 on the date of entry of this Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check made payable to the Treasurer of the United States and delivered to: the Office of Consumer Litigation, Civil Division, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, D.C. 20530, for appropriate disposition.

provisions.title: Default Payment Consequences
provisions.summary: If defendants default on payment for more than 10 days, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due.

requirements.description: Pay full penalty plus interest if default exceeds 10 days
requirements.quoted_text: In the event of any default in payment, which default continues for ten (10) days beyond the due date of payment, the entire unpaid penalty, together with interest, as computed pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1961, from the date of default to the date of payment, shall immediately become due and payable.

provisions.title: Deletion of Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must delete all personal information collected from children through their website from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry.

requirements.description: Delete all children's personal information collected during specified period
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall delete all personal information collected from children through www.girlslife.com at any time from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of this Consent Decree.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Order - Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide to current personnel with relevant responsibilities, obtain signed acknowledgments, and report compliance to the Commission within 10 days.

requirements.description: Distribute order and compliance guide to current personnel, obtain signed acknowledgments, and submit compliance statement
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the Federal Trade Commission compliance guide entitled How to Comply with the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (Nov. 1999) ("compliance guide") (attached hereto as "Appendix B") to each of their current principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the subject matter of this Consent Decree, secure from each such person a signed statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide, and shall, within ten (10) days of complying with this paragraph, submit to the Commission a signed statement setting forth the fact and manner of defendants' compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide has been provided.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Order - Future Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide to future personnel with relevant responsibilities within 30 days of their assuming such positions, obtain signed acknowledgments, and maintain records.

requirements.description: Distribute order and compliance guide to future personnel within 30 days, obtain acknowledgments, and maintain records
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide to each of their future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all future employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the subject matter of this Consent Decree, and secure from each such person a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide, within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities. Defendants shall maintain copies of the signed statements, as well as other information regarding the fact and manner of their compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide has been provided and, upon request, shall make the statements and other information available to the Federal Trade Commission.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must file detailed written compliance reports with the Commission within 60 days of entry and at other times as required, covering privacy notices, parental consent methods, and security procedures.

requirements.description: File detailed compliance report within 60 days and as required thereafter
requirements.quoted_text: Within sixty (60) days after entry of this Consent Decree, and at such other times as the Federal Trade Commission may require, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall file with the Commission a written report, sworn to under penalty of perjury, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which they have complied and are complying with this Consent Decree.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping and Document Retention
provisions.summary: For five years from entry, defendants must maintain and make available to the FTC within seven days all documents demonstrating compliance, including web pages, forms, and privacy-related materials.

requirements.description: Maintain compliance documents for 5 years and produce to FTC within 7 days of request
requirements.quoted_text: For a period of five years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall maintain and make available to the Federal Trade Commission for inspection and copying within seven (7) days of the date of receipt of a written request, a print or electronic copy in HTML format of all documents demonstrating compliance with the terms and provisions of this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, a sample copy of every information collection form, web page, or screen, and a sample copy of each document containing any representation regarding defendants' collection, use, and disclosure practices pertaining to personal information.

provisions.title: Notice of Business Changes
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the Commission at least 30 days before any business changes that may affect compliance obligations, including mergers, dissolutions, or corporate structure changes.

requirements.description: Notify Commission 30 days before business changes affecting compliance
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the business of defendants that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, any merger, incorporation, dissolution, assignment, sale or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address.

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identification Numbers
provisions.summary: Defendants must furnish their taxpayer identifying numbers to the FTC for collection and reporting purposes.

requirements.description: Provide taxpayer identification numbers to FTC
requirements.quoted_text: Defendants are hereby required, in accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701, to furnish to the Federal Trade Commission each of their taxpayer identifying numbers (social security number or employer identification number), which shall be used for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amount arising out of their relationship with the government.

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction to interpret, modify, enforce, or punish violations of the Consent Decree.

requirements.description: Court retains jurisdiction for interpretation, modification, enforcement, and violation punishment
requirements.quoted_text: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to this Consent Decree to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.

duration.termination_text: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to this Consent Decree to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.
